questions.text: Upload photos of the damage or area needing repair. (REQUIRED — structural repair cannot be quoted without photos)
questions.hint: Take photos from multiple angles. Include close-ups of cracks, rust-through, bends, or broken welds. Show the overall structure for context. A ruler or tape measure in the photo helps us gauge scale.

options: Bent / deformed member — straighten or replace
Broken / severed member — reattach or replace

questions.text: What is the item or structure being repaired?

questions.hint: Example: '20 ft flatbed trailer', '16 ft enclosed cargo trailer', '40 ft gooseneck'. Include GVWR if known.

questions.text: Does this repair need DOT certification or inspection?
options: No — not a road vehicle / not DOT regulated
questions.hint: DOT-certified frame repairs require specific procedures, documentation, and often a certified welder. This adds significant cost and limits who can perform the work. We can refer to a DOT-certified shop if needed.

questions.text: What is the material being repaired?
questions.hint: IMPORTANT: HSLA steels (T1, A514, AR400, Hardox) require preheat and controlled interpass temperature. Welding HSLA cold causes hydrogen cracking. If in doubt, assume HSLA and preheat.

questions.text: HSLA steel preheat advisory: This material requires preheat (typically 200-400°F) and specific low-hydrogen electrodes (E7018 or ER70S-6). Cold welding HSLA steel will crack. Acknowledged?
options: Not sure it's HSLA — can you test?
questions.hint: We can test material with a hardness tester or spark test. If the original weld filler is unknown, we default to HSLA procedures for safety.

questions.text: Cast iron/steel repair advisory: Cast repairs are specialized work requiring nickel rod, preheat, and slow cooling. Success rate is lower than structural steel repair. Proceed?
options: Evaluate and advise (may need replacement part instead)
questions.hint: Cast iron repairs can fail if the piece has hidden internal cracks or is heavily stressed. Consider whether a fabricated replacement is more reliable.

questions.text: Approximate size of the damaged area?
questions.hint: Example: '6 inch crack along weld', '2 ft section of rusted-through tube', '8 inch bend in beam'. Be as specific as possible.

questions.text: What are the member sizes being repaired? (if known)
questions.hint: Example: '4x4x1/4 square tube', 'W8x31 beam', '3/8 plate'. If unknown, we'll determine from photos.

questions.text: How will we access the repair area?
questions.hint: Shop repairs are almost always faster, cheaper, and higher quality than field repairs. If the item can be transported, bring it to the shop.

options: Emergency — equipment is down, losing money
questions.hint: Emergency/rush repairs typically incur a 25-50% premium for overtime and schedule disruption.

questions.text: Where is the job site or where will you bring the item?
questions.hint: City or zip code. If bringing to shop, just note that.

questions.text: Any additional photos showing the full structure or context?
questions.hint: Wide-angle shots showing how the damaged area relates to the overall structure help us plan the repair approach.
